description:
Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV) is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus that belongs to the Polyomaviridae family. It was first identified in 2008 and is the causative agent of Merkel cell carcinoma, a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer.

The virus has a circular, double-stranded DNA genome that encodes several proteins, including the large T antigen and small T antigen, which play crucial roles in the virus's replication and transformation of host cells. MCPyV is believed to be a common member of the human skin microbiome, with a high prevalence in the general population.

The virus typically infects the Merkel cells, a specialized mechanoreceptor cell type found in the basal layer of the epidermis. In some cases, the viral DNA integrates into the host cell genome, leading to the development of Merkel cell carcinoma, a highly aggressive and often fatal form of skin cancer.

Ongoing research focuses on understanding the mechanisms by which MCPyV contributes to the development of Merkel cell carcinoma, as well as the potential therapeutic strategies to target this virus and its associated malignancy.
